description.narrative:
Partnerskapet för kvinnors-, barns- och ungdomshälsa, PMNCH (ibland endast Partnerskapet) är världens största internationella partnerskap som syftar till att förbättra mödra-, barn och ungdomshälsan i världen. PMNCH har sökt bidrag till sin strategiska plan 2016-2020 genom förverkligandet av sin affärsplan för 2018-2020.
PMNCH skapades år 2005 med syfte att öka förutsättningarna för världens fattiga länder att uppnå milleniemålen 4 och 5 i en tid då resurser och politiskt engagemang för mödra-, barn och ungdomshälsa inte stod högst på den globala dagordningen. Idag omfattar partnerskapet över 1000 medlemmar som representerar länder i Syd, givare, multilateraler, akademiska institutioner, privata aktörer, civilsamhällsorganisationer, yrkesprofessionella organ samt ungdomsorganisationer. PMNCH har ett mindre sekretariat som huserar hos WHO i Geneve. Förutom att stärka partnerskapet kring huvudfrågorna är sekretariatets uppgift att samordna arbetet i partnerskapet med ett fokus på analys, ansvarsutkrävande, påverkansarbete och landengagemang. Kopplingen till FN:s globala strategi för kvinnors, barns och ungdomars hälsa 2016-2030 är institutionaliserad genom att PMNCH fått ett särskilt ansvar från FN:s generalsekreterare att följa upp genomförandet av den globala strategin och arbeta fram indikatorer för detta ändamål. En självständig panel, Independent Accountability Panel, har tillsatts som årligen rapporterar på efterlevnad av länders åtaganden och måluppföljning. Sida sitter i PMNCHS styrelse sedan 2013 och driver särskilt frågan om ett utökat fokus kring SRHR inklusive rätten till säkra aborter. Sida och Sveriges roll i partnerskapet är central med anledning av Sveriges starka engagemang och höga finansiering av SRHR globalt.
PMNCHs affärsplan för 2018-2020 har en budget på 30 miljoner USD. Den är finansierad av ca 15 givare från bilaterala organisationer, privata stiftelser och FN. Sidas bidrag är 12 MSEK under tre år (2019-2022), vilket utgör ca 4 % av den totala budgeten.

The Partnership for Women, Child and Adolescents' Health, PMNCH (in short referred to as the Partnership) is the world's largest international partnership aimed at improving maternal, child and adolescents' health in the world. PMNCH has applied for a contribution to its strategic plan 2016-2020 by realizing its business plan for 2018-2020.
PMNCH was created in 2005 with the aim of improving the conditions for the world's poor countries to achieve Millennium Goals 4 and 5 at a time when resources and political commitment to maternal, child and adolescents health were not high on the global agenda. Today, the partnership includes over 1,000-member organisations representing countries in the South, donors, multilateral, academic institutions, private actors, civil society organizations, professional bodies, and youth organizations. PMNCH has a small secretariat that is housed at the WHO in Geneva. In addition to strengthening the partnership on the main issues, the secretariat's task is to coordinate and align the work in the partnership with a focus on analysis, accountability, advocacy and country engagement. The link to the UN's global strategy for women's, children's and adolescents' health (2016-2030) is institutionalized by PMNCH being given a special responsibility by the UN Secretary-General to follow up the implementation of the global strategy and to develop indicators for this purpose. An independent panel, the Independent Accountability Panel, has been appointed to report annually on compliance of countries' commitments. Sida is a member of the PMNCHs board since 2013 and in particular advocaet for and monitor the issue of an expanded focus on SRHR including the right to safe abortions. Sida and Sweden's role in the partnership is central to Sweden's strong commitment and high funding of SRHR globally.
PMNCH's business plan for 2018-2020 has a budget of $ 30 million. It is funded by 15 donors from bilateral organizations, private foundations and the UN. Sida's contribution is SEK 12 million for three years (2019-2022), which represents about 4% of the total budget.

The vision, mission and objectives of the partnership has changed with their recently launched strategy 2021-25 however is still in line with the Sida-PMNCH agreement objectives.
The Partnerships vision is a world in which every woman, child and adolescent is able to realize their right to health and well-being, leaving no one behind. Our mission is to mobilize, align and amplify the voices of partners to advocate for womens, childrens and adolescents health and well-being, particularly the most vulnerable. Our time is now.
PMCNH will drive forward three interconnected objectives over the period of this new Strategy:
Maternal, newborn and child health (MNCH): to drive down preventable morbidity and mortality, including stillbirths, by advocating vigorously for the inclusion of essential MNCH services in costed country benefits packages.
Sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR): to uphold essential SRHR interventions and ensure continuous progress in financing and equitable access to comprehensive SRHR packages.
Adolescents: to advance the health and well-being of adolescents by engaging, aligning and capacitating partners around the Adolescent Well-Being Framework and related policies and actions.
Intermediary objectives include: Knowledge synthesis: increased use of evidence and policy analysis by decision-makers and other actors. Partner engagement: increased advocacy capacity and stronger coalitions built among PMNCH partners at country, regional and global levels, for a more effective voice. Campaigns and outreach: champions work facilitated, political support increased and agendas influenced.
With advocacy as the core function supported by knowledge synthesis, partner engagement, campaigns and outreach we will mobilize and resource our partners to seek changes in policy, financing and services for women, children and adolescents, and we will hold each other accountable for delivering on our promises. As well as working in the health sector, we will also contribute to and track outcomes of other sectors relating to major determinants of health outcomes, such as education, water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) and economic development.
PMNCH will deliver this Strategy with a partnership-centric approach, engaging, amplifying and aligning partners through a digital-led strategy of partner engagement. It will streamline its governance and Secretariat support functions over the Strategy period to deliver more efficiently and to drive value-for money and results.
PMNCHS CORE VALUE PROPOSITION IS THREE-FOLD: Thematic focus: PMNCH is the largest global multistakeholder partnership focusing on WCAH and on the entire continuum of care.
Breadth: as of 2020, PMNCH has more than 1,000 partners, organized into 10 constituencies (Figure 1) across 192 countries; no other partnership has such breadth, diversity and penetration.
Convening power: PMNCH has the power to convene at the highest level and to act with pace and urgency through a global network of partners (at country, regional and global levels), hosted by WHO but with independent governance and with the richness and breadth of its large and diverse membership.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

title.narrative: Beslut om insats - PMNCH 2019-2021 (Partnership for Maternal, Newborn and Child Health)
Grant Agreement- PMNCH 2019-2021 (Partnership for Maternal, Newborn and Child Health)

description.narrative: The year 2020 took a different turn of events due to the pandemic, however it has offered opportunities for closer and more strategic collaboration. PMNCH re-focused their work to ensure WCAH services as part of the pandemic response and have been working hard to advocate for this while going through substantial governance and strategic reforms. The organisation has some 'finding itself' to do in their new strategy but it seems they are on the right track. 2020 was a transition year for PMNCH, they drafted their new strategy (2021-2023) and they worked hard to respond to the evaluation that came out early 2020. The evaluation had several points of criticism of issues that Sida too has identified as high risk of the contribution and PMCNCH have responded with a solid management response plan and were quick to turn around the recommendations into governance and structural changes in the partnership strucutre. The evaluation report and response can be found on their website. Some of the key areas of criticism include being a top-heavy and bureucratic organization that does not foster grass-roots mobilization and partnership, the lack of a coherent agenda and the secretariat spreading themselves thin wanting to do more than their mandate and capacity allows. The new strategy is much stronger and more focused and places PMNCH as a more strategic and stringent actor in the field where the sole focus is on advocacy using the strength and expertise within its broad partnership. The strategy has three priority areas including maternal and child health (MNCH), adolescent health and well-being, and sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Sida particularly appreciates the stronger focus on comprehensive SRHR as part of the strategy, as well as the advocacy focus to allow the partnership to be more effective. To summarize some of the key results of PMNCH in 2019 (based on annual report in Nov 2019):- The partnership was important in the lead up to integrating SRHR in UHC and its advocacy during 2019- The focus and work around adolescents have increased significantly, and a number of initiatives and technical resources have been developed including the adolescent health and wellbeing framework.- The partnership has started to explore how it can contribute to MNCAH in humanitarian settings and have held consultations and written a value proposition. - The partnership supported CSOs and particularly youth engagement in the Global Financing Facility (GFF) national plan development and facilitated global, regional and national level consultations. This resulted in the GFF adding an AY section to their civil society engagement strategy. A few results during 2020 (the report will be shared in June): - Hosted two 'Lives in a Balance' Summits together with UHC2030 to situate SRMNCAH at the center of the pandemic response. This rallied commitments by governments and partners. - A 7-point Call to Action on Covid-19 and WCAH was launched in July during the first Summit. - The adolescent Call to Action continues to rally signatories and are planning for an Adolsecent Summit in 2023. In response of the evaluation report, the partnership has also gone through a significant governance reform using participatory and conslutatory measures to ensure consensus among constituencies. The structure of the board has also been rearranged and will be a smaller but more effective board moving forward. Sida/ Sweden were alternates to Canada in the previous board, however did not apply for a seat in the new constallation to allow for other partners to play a more active roll. Sida is engaged in the donor and foundation constituency where we are pushing for stronger emphasis of comprehensive SRHR, meaningful youth participation and advocacy through existing platforms and networks rather than setting up new.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
